I am also satisfied that the board make special efforts to secure that there is no avoidable delay in dealing with cases which could have a significant impact on job creation.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Dublin Bay Pollution.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Andrews Mr. D. Andrews
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he is aware of the continuing pollution in Dublin Bay and that there are moneys available within the EC for the control of such pollution; the reason no funds have been sought to date; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: Water quality in Dublin Bay is monitored on behalf of the local authorities by the Eastern Health Board. I am advised that in the opinion of the health board the waters do not constitute a threat to public health. My Department have made extensive funding available to the Dublin authorities to improve the sewerage disposal arrangements in the bay area. Last May, the greater Dublin drainage scheme which cost in excess of £50 million was commissioned. I have approved proposals for the Blackrock main drainage scheme (Stage 1) and Phase II of the Ringsend treatment works which have a combined estimated cost of £10 million. These schemes should result in further improvements in water quality.

I am not aware of the availability of any EC funds specifically for pollution control schemes of the kind to which the question relates. However, the European Regional Development Fund can, in certain circumstances, assist in the provision of improved sewerage treatment schemes and moneys have, in fact, been committed from the fund for schemes in progress or recently completed in Dublin city and county. These schemes have an estimated cost of £71.72 million and fund commitments in respect of them total £11.291 million.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Finglas (Dublin) Environmental Improvements.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will make special funds available for a scheme of environmental improvements in the Finglas south low cost housing scheme, which is in urgent need of upgrading, and if he will meet, at an early date, representatives of residents to discuss the needs of the area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: The initiative for tackling improvements in a particular housing estate rests with the responsible housing authority, in this case Dublin Corporation. It would, therefore, be more appropriate for the residents of the area in question to put any proposals which they may have for improving their environment directly to the corporation. If proposals relating to the improvement of the Finglas south housing estate are made to me by the corporation, I will, of course, consider them fully.

MainHeading.P: The Deputy will be aware of the Government's decision to make £5 million available in 1986 for a new programme of improved community and leisure facilities and other general amenities, particularly in areas of social need. I am considering proposals from Dublin Corporation and other bodies concerning the funding of projects under this scheme and hope to be in a position to make an announcement shortly in the matter.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Baldoyle (Dublin) Housing Estate.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Woods Dr. Woods
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment, in view of the widespread and established defects in the construction of the roofs of houses built by Dublin Corporation in Seagrange Estate, Baldoyle, Dublin 13, and the continuing damage and hardship being experienced by residents, if he will provide the necessary finance to repair these roofs using A-type roof construction.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: Grant assistance of up to two-thirds of the approved cost, subject to a maximum of £2,000 is available under the new house improvement grants scheme for the carrying out of necessary repairs to the basic fabric of a house including the provision, if necessary, of a new roof. It is a matter for the persons concerned, should they wish to avail of this scheme, to submit applications in the normal way to my Department. As regards an application made by Dublin Corporation for assistance under my Department's remedial works scheme in relation to this estate, I would refer the Deputy to my reply to Question No. 26 of 11 December 1985.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Dunleer (Louth) By-pass

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bell Mr. Bell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the level of financial support from his Department and the EC for the Dunleer by-pass, County Louth; if he is aware of the very bad state of the existing road, when he expects work to commence and conclude; if way-leave has been completed with land and property owners; if so, the cost involved; the projected employment involved; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I expect to be in a position shortly to reach a decision on Louth County Council's motorway scheme in respect of the proposed Dunleer by-pass which has been estimated to cost £15 million at 1984 prices. I am sure the Deputy will appreciate that in view of my quasi-judicial functions in the matter it would not be appropriate for me to make any comments on the details of the scheme in advance of any decision.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Roads.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West) asked the Minister for the Environment if he will consider allocating a special grant to local authorities in 1986 for the improvement of county roads.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: The primary responsibility for the planning and execution of improvement works on county roads rests with local authorities. The expenditure involved falls to be financed by the local authorities from their own resources which may be supplemented by the block grant for roads paid annually by my Department. The manner in which the block grant is spent, including the extent, if any, to which it is to be applied to improvement works on county roads, is largely a matter for each local authority.

The road grants notified to local authorities for 1986 include a sum of £20.4 million which has been allocated by way of block grant. This is 21 per cent higher than the corresponding grant in 1985. In addition, grant commitments totalling £3 million are being notified to county councils this year to finance improvement works on county roads used mainly for agriculture or forestry, in those parts of the country coming within the scope of the EC western package. This represents an increase of £1 million compared with 1985.

MainHeading.P: It is not possible at this stage to allocate any additional road grants to any local authority because the funds available in 1986 have been fully allocated. The Department are monitoring progress on grant-aided works during 1986. If it should appear later this year that the grant allocated to a local authority will not be required in full in 1986, the authority will be consulted and any possible savings will be reallocated to other authorities which require the additional funds and can spend the money involved this year.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - National House Building Guarantee Scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if his Department will review the national house building guarantee scheme in light of the serious financial consequences for house purchasers of unfinished estates, insolvencies and builders going into liquidation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: The national house building guarantee scheme is operated by a company established under the aegis of the Construction Industry Federation and provides a structural guarantee of new houses registered under the scheme. A review of the scheme is primarily a matter for the guarantee company itself and I have no direct function in the matter. My Department have, however, pursued the question of deposit cover with the company on a number of occasions and have again recently asked the company to further examine the question. I understand that the company is considering the matter in the context of a general review of its rules and I hope to be informed shortly of the outcome. It is a matter for each planning authority to take appropriate action to deal with the problem of unfinished estates.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Road Safety Improvement.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. O'Hanlon Dr. O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he is concerned at the risk to safety caused by the deterioration in the surface of many of our roads; and the plans he has to restore them to an acceptable level.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: The improvement of road safety and the preservation, through proper maintenance, of existing and planned road investment are among the main aims of the Government's road development policy. The strategy for implementation of this policy and the manner of financing of the policy are set out in chapter 3 of the road plan which I published in January 1985. The major road improvements carried out in recent years and the improvement in the standard of maintenance of the principal traffic routes in this period have been important factors in the reduction of 38 per cent in the number of road deaths from 628 in 1978 to 416 in 1985.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Cork Road Improvement.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Walsh Mr. J. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will make a special grant available for road improvement in the vicinity of Ballinspittle, County Cork, and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: On 10 December 1985 a special grant of £50,000 was notified to Cork County Council to finance a portion of the cost of road improvement works in the vicinity of Ballinspittle. The balance of the cost is being met by the local authority.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Housing Statistics.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the number of houses completed in 1985 (a) by private contractors and (b) by local authorities; and the effect that the imposition of the extra 5 per cent VAT on the construction industry had on house building in 1985.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: It is estimated that 17,000 private houses and 6,500 local authority houses were completed in 1985. It is not possible to estimate the precise effects of the increase in the building services rate of VAT on new housing output in 1985. It is likely, however, that any effects on output will have been largely offset by the increase in the new house grant, the effect of the £5,000 grant to certain local authority tenants and tenant purchasers to enable them to build or buy their own houses, and the continued high level of the local authority housing programme and the publicly funded house purchase loan schemes.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - SDA Fixed Interest Loans.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Land Usage.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wallace Mr. Wallace
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he considers the concepts of land use in 1986 to be different from the concepts of land use in 1963 when the principal planning Act was introduced; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: The point at issue in the question is not clear. The Local Government (Planning and Development) Act, 1963, requires each planning authority to make a development plan indicating objectives which, in the case of county boroughs, boroughs, urban districts and scheduled towns, must include the zoning of land for residential, commercial, industrial, agricultural or other uses. While it would be possible to list other categories of land use, I do not consider that any useful purpose would be served by amending the 1963 Act in this respect.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Mayo Roads.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he is aware of the dangerous condition of many county roads in County Mayo because of the failure of the Government to honour the terms of the Local Government Financial Provisions Act, 1978; the action he proposes to take to provide the county council with the necessary funds to safeguard the enormous investment of ratepayers and taxpayers; and whether he will provide funds to enable the county council to carry out (a) the necessary repairs and (b) a reasonable programme for respraying on those roads.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I am aware of the condition of roads generally including county roads in County Mayo. Primary responsibility for the planning and execution of works on county roads rests with the local authorities. The expenditure involved falls to be financed by the local authorities from their own resources which may be supplemented, in the case of improvement works, by the block grant for roads paid annually by my Department. The manner in which the block grant is spent, including the extent to which it is to be applied to improvement works on county roads, is largely a matter within the discretion of each local authority.

MainHeading.P: A block grant of £909,000 has been notified to Mayo County Council for 1986, which is an increase of 33 per cent compared with 1985. In addition, since 1981, the local authority has benefited from funds provided specifically for the improvement of county roads under the EC western package. Grant commitments to the local authority to date under the Package total £1.56 million.

In accordance with the practice established by successive Governments, road grants are not provided to finance the cost of maintaining county roads. Expenditure under this heading falls to be financed from the local authority's own resources. In this connection, may I remind the Deputy that the Government decided this year to abolish the levy on local authorities in respect of the supplementary welfare allowance scheme. The effect of this, combined with the increase in the rate support grants, notified to the local authority in December last, was to make an additional £1 million available to Mayo County Council to meet their commitments in 1986. Moreover, the 1986 rate support grant has just been increased further in the context of the budget. This will give an additional £171,000 to the local authority in the current year. I am confident that these additional funds will enable the authority to maintain its services at a satisfactory level in 1986.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Donegal Roads.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will direct officials of his Department in conjunction with council engineers, to carry out a survey of all roads in County Donegal which are in urgent need of repairs; and if he will then, having received a report, consider allocating a special grant for the repair of the roads in most urgent need of repair.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I am aware of the general condition of roads in County Donegal on the basis of inspections carried out by my Department's inspector for the area and reports submitted by Donegal County Council. I do not consider it necessary to have a special survey carried out along the lines proposed by the Deputy.

The State grants for roads allocated to Donegal County Council for 1986 totalled £6.318 million. This represents an increase of 9 per cent relative to the original allocation notified to the local authority in 1985.
The position regarding State grants for maintenance works is, as follows:

(1) Full cost grants are provided by the Department for approved programmes of surface dressing and ordinary maintenance on national roads. I am satisfied that the grants allocated to the local authority for these purposes in the current year are sufficient to provide a good standard of maintenance on these roads. The grant allocation notified to the local authority in 1986 for maintenance works on national roads is £978,000, which is 7 per cent higher than the corresponding payments made to the authority in 1985.

(2) Expenditure on maintenance works on regional roads falls to be financed by the local authority from their own resources, which may be supplemented by the block grant for roads paid annually by the Department. The manner in which the block grant is spent, including the extent to which it is to be applied to maintenance works on regional roads, is largely within the discretion of each local authority. The block grant allocated to the local authority in 1986 is £1.04 million, which is 10 per cent higher than the corresponding grant in 1985.

MainHeading.P: (3) In accordance with the practice established by successive Governments, it is not proposed to make State grants available for county road maintenance. Expenditure under this heading will continue to be financed by local authorities from their own resources.

It is not possible at this stage to allocate any additional road grants to any local authority because the funds available in 1986 have been fully allocated. The Department are monitoring progress on grant-aided works during 1986. If it should appear later this year that the grant allocated to a local authority will not be required in full in 1986, the authority will be consulted and any possible savings will be reallocated to other authorities which require the additional funds and can spend the money involved this year.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Power Devolution to Local Authorities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the exact powers which he has devolved to local authorities since the election of 1985.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: As I have already stated in the House, devolution on the scale envisaged in the Policy Statement on the Reform of Local Government, which I issued on 30 May 1985 is a major undertaking and will be implemented in stages following careful analysis of the organisational and procedural implications of each proposal. The purpose of such examination is to avoid duplication of services and to ensure that there will be no net addition to the cost of services. The necessary examinations involving several Departments are taking place under the supervision of the devolution implementation group chaired by the Minister for the Public Service as provided for in the policy statement.

In the case of my own Department consultations with staff interests are proceeding, as provided for in the policy statement, with a view to the implementation of arrangements for devolution of work in the grants areas without disruption of the public services concerned.

MainHeading.P: Arrangements for devolving the administration of the Dublin inner city programme and fund to Dublin Corporation have been finalised and are expected to be in operation shortly. Further devolution provisions will be included in legislation on local government reorganisation and on road traffic matters which will be coming forward later this year. Given the complexities involved significant progress is being made and it is the intention to proceed with implementation of the programme with all feasible speed.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Taxing of Derelict Sites.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias de Rossa Proinsias de Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment when it is proposed to introduce the annual 10 per cent tax on derelict sites, which was promised in the Fine Gael-Labour Joint Programme for Government.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I refer the Deputy to a reply by the Minister for Finance to a related question from the Deputy — Official Report, Volume 361, columns 720 and 721. The question of a tax on derelict sites is being considered but complex issues, such as the need to discriminate between genuine developers and speculators and the impact on the building industry, still need to be resolved.

On the general question of dereliction in urban areas, the report of the Joint Committee on Building Land recommended measures designed to improve the supply of urban land and I am having these considered. I propose to bring forward legislation to consolidate and modernise the powers of local authorities in relation to the acquisition and disposal of land and this will, among other things, enable local authorities to deal more effectively with derelict sites.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Price Increase Effects.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism if he is aware that the recent price increases will result in further closure of business in Border counties; and if he will outline the steps he proposes to take to prevent further job losses.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. J. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. J. Bruton)
Speaker.P: The taxation changes in the recent budget will have a stimulatory effect on business generally. As a result of the budget prices in general will rise by no more than one-half per cent and these price increases will not have any significant effect on business or employment nationally.

The Government have been aware of the difficulties experienced by certain traders in the Border areas because of price competition from Northern Ireland. In order to alleviate these difficulties the Government have taken steps in recent years as follows:
—substantial reduction in the duty on spirits in 1984;
—halving of the duty on televisions in the 1985 budget;
—abolition of the 35 per cent rate of VAT;
—announcement of abolition of the duty on motor vehicle spare parts and accessories, tyres and tubes.

MainHeading.P: These changes benefit the traders concerned and help maintain and create jobs. Furthermore the changes taking place in the VAT treatment of areas of the services industry from 1 July 1986 should have considerable benefits for the economy generally. Border counties will share in the benefits of these tax changes particularly in so far as they affect tourism.
As part of their overall policy on employment and job maintenance and creation the Government keep the level and incidence of taxation under review.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: The house improvement grants scheme is not yet in operation a sufficient period of time to give an accurate assessment of the average length of time between receipt of an application and the carrying out of an inspection. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Reweighing of Commercial Vehicles.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kenny Mr. Kenny
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he is aware of any complaints in relation to commercial vehicles having to be reweighed at a charge prior to owners being able to retax such vehicles; and if he will comment on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I have not received any complaints on this issue. It is not customary for licensing authorities to require certificates of unladen weight of goods vehicles on renewal of road tax unless there is reason to believe a vehicle has been modified to such extent as to affect the unladen weight on which the tax is chargeable.

Following the transfer of ownership of a goods vehicle, certain licensing authorities require the new owner to present the vehicle for reweighing prior to relicensing the vehicle in the name of the new owner. My Department proposes to ask licensing authorities generally to limit this practice to cases where the licensing authority have reason to believe that the new owner has modified the vehicle in such a way as to affect the unladen weight of the vehicle involved. When a vehicle is presented for weighing for licensing purposes a relatively small fee is charged for the use of the appointed weighbridge involved. Inquiries made by my Department of a sample number of licensing authorities indicated that the fees generally do not exceed £5.

Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 67 and 68 together. This case concerns a claim by a former employee of An Foras Forbartha who is now employed by the Institute for Industrial Research and Standards for payment of a lump sum in respect of a period while employed with An Foras and which was related to revised working arrangements and future productivity. MainHeading.P: Following are the road grant allocations notified to local authorities for 1986:

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Connolly Mr. Connolly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the amount of money allocated per mile for county roads in each county for 1984, 1985 and 1986.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I presume the Deputy is referring to road grants provided by my Department. Road grant assistance towards the cost of works on county roads normally forms part of the block grant paid annually by my Department. This grant supplements the provision made from local authorities' own resources for the improvement, maintenance and management of non-national main roads, for improvement works on county roads, and for the implementation of traffic management measures. The manner in which the block grant is spent, the extent to which it is apportioned to county road improvement, and the rate per mile of county roads which this represents are largely within the discretion of each local authority. In the circumstances, I am not in a position to provide the information sought by the Deputy.

Block grants allocated to local authorities for 1986 total £20.4 million which is 21 per cent higher than the equivalent grants in 1985 which, in turn, were 10 per cent greater than the 1984 grants. In accordance with the practice of successive Governments, State road grants are not made available for county road maintenance. Expenditure under this heading falls to be met from local authorities' own resources.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Custom Clearance Facilities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if he is aware of the changes in Customs clearance facilities at Northern Ireland Customs posts; and the steps he has taken to protect industries that use these facilities.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: I am assuming that the Deputy is referring to the exportation of refrigerated goods from County Donegal, across the land frontier, in respect of which he has made representations to my Department.

I am not aware that any changes of the kind referred to have been brought about recently, but I have requested the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Revenue Commissioners to take the matter up with the appropriate authorities in Northern Ireland.

I understand, from preliminary inquiries made by the Revenue Commissioners, that changes in the present customs clearance arrangements are being considered by the customs administration in Northern Ireland but that, in the event of any changes, that administration is prepared to facilitate regular traders in perishable goods where actual customs attendance is not provided outside the ordinary hours of Customs business.

Speaker.P: There will be no reduction in the service normally provided by my Department to owners of restricted herds. The elimination of disease from such herds will continue to be a priority throughout 1986.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Beef Exports to Canada.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the steps he proposes to take to ensure that Irish beef will continue to be marketed in Canada.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: When it became apparent late last year that the Canadian authorities were actively considering further restrictions on imports of Community beef, I immediately took the matter up with the Commission which negotiates for the Community in matters of this kind. My Department have been constantly in touch with them since then and have focused attention on the implications for Ireland of any such restrictive measures. It is understood that the Commission have now reached a provisional agreement with Canada, subject to ratification, and that this would allow trade to continue at the same level as in 1985, viz, 10,668 tonnes.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Grant Payments.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will expedite approval and payments of various grants due to a person (details supplied) in County Roscommon.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The person named was ineligible for aid under the feed voucher scheme because he was assessed as having more than 75 per cent of his fodder requirements as calculated in accordance with the conditions of the scheme. He has been paid his sheep headage and ewe premium grants already and will be paid his cattle headage, suckler cow and calf premium grants shortly.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Feed Voucher Scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Farrelly Mr. Farrelly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the reason a feed voucher has been refused to a person (details supplied) in County Cavan.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The person concerned was rejected for aid under the feed voucher scheme on the basis of the information supplied by him on his application form, showing that he had more than 75 per cent of his fodder requirements as calculated in accordance with the conditions of the scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Farrelly Mr. Farrelly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the reason a feed voucher has been refused to a person (details supplied) in County Meath.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The application from the person concerned was not processed as it was received after the extended closing date for receipt of applications.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Repair of Cavan Courthouse.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the present position with regard to the provision of courthouse accommodation in Cavan town.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): Consequent on the making absolute by the High Court of a conditional Order of Mandamus and under the authority of section 6 (1) (a) of the Courthouses (Provision and Maintenance) Act, 1935, I recently directed the Commissioners for Public Works to execute such repairs and to do such other works as may be necessary or proper to put the court accommodation at Farnham Street, Cavan into proper repair or condition.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Skerries (Dublin) Crime Level.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is aware of the serious concern of the people of Skerries regarding the crime situation in their area; and his proposals to improve the situation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I appreciate that there is concern in the Skerries area, as there is in other areas, at the present level of crime. However, provisional crime figures for 1985 for the Garda sub-district of Skerries indicate some decrease in crime in comparison with 1984 and 1983 figures.

Garda strength in the sub-district of Skerries has been increased from one sergeant and five gardaí in 1983 to one sergeant and nine gardaí at present. The crime position and policing needs of Skerries will continue to be kept under review by the Garda authorities.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Gaming and Lotteries Legislation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Byrne Mr. S. Byrne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if there is any liaison between licensing authorities for national collections which are issued in Dublin and local collections as there is a constant flow of professional ticket sellers and collectors invading local towns and interfering with local fund-raising activities.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): A collection permit under the Street and House to House Collection Act, 1962, relates only to a particular locality. As regards lotteries permits for occasional lotteries with a prize-fund limited to £300 may be granted under section 27 of the Gaming and Lotteries Act, 1956, by Garda superintendents.

I assume, however, that the question is intended to relate primarily to periodical lotteries which are subject to a District Court licensing requirement but in relation to which ticket-sales may take place outside (as well as inside) the Court District where the licence is granted.

MainHeading.P: As the licensing function in this matter is exercised by the court it would be inappropriate for me to say more at this point than that I do not think the matters referred to in the second part of the question are matters likely to be very significantly affected by liaison or lack of it but, in any event, a review of the gaming and lotteries legislation is proceeding and there should be an opportunity for all Deputies to contribute to a debate on all aspects of it in the not too distant future.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - UCD Athletic Track.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will make moneys available for resurfacing the athletic track at UCD, Belfield, in view of its present poor condition and the fact that it is a major amenity on Dublin south side and an international venue.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: University College, Dublin, is statutorily required to make any request for State funds through the Higher Education Authority. I understand that the authority has not received a request from UCD for moneys to be made available for resurfacing the athletic track at the college. Any such request would have to be considered in the context of the overall allocation to UCD for 1986 bearing in mind that in the absence of a formal request from the college authorities a specific provision was not made in the 1986 Capital Programme of expenditure for this purpose.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Grant Payment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Browne Mr. Browne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when a grant which was sanctioned over two years ago for a school (details supplied) in County Wexford will be paid.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The grant referred to was sanctioned in respect of a prefabricated building which was found on first inspection not to have been completed in a satisfactory manner. Arrangements have been made for a further inspection at an early date with a view, if possible, to making a payment. I am asking that the matter be dealt with as quickly as possible.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Tallaght (Dublin) Regional Technical College.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will make a statement on the progress of the development of the regional technical college project for Tallaght, County Dublin; if provision of this facility can be expedited; and when the facility is likely to be available to serve the Tallaght area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Architectural planning of the new college has started and every effort is being made to complete the planning process without undue delay. At this early stage, it is not possible to say when the facility is likely to be available.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Donnybrook (Dublin) National School.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Doyle Mr. J. Doyle
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when the chairman of the board of management of St. Mary's national school, Donnybrook, will receive notification to commence work on the school extension.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Tenders for the extension of St. Mary's national school, Donnybrook, are at present being examined in my Department. A decision on the question of the commencement of work on this project will be conveyed to the school authorities as soon as possible.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Registration of Architects.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she has any proposals to bring legislation before the Dáil regarding the registration of architects.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: I have no proposals at present to bring forward legislation regarding the registration of architects.

MainHeading.P: This, however, is one of a number of matters being considered by the various Departments concerned in the context of the EC Directive of 10 June 1985 on the mutual recognition of diplomas, certificates and other evidence of formal qualifications in architecture, including measures to facilitate the effective exercise of the right of establishment and freedom to provide services. I do not, therefore, at this stage, wish to rule out the possibility of legislation.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Redundancy Payments.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the reason for the delay in giving a decision on the redundancy payment application of a person (details supplied) in County Dublin, if a decision can be given quickly in view of his need; and when this decision can be expected.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: I understand that the decision of the Employment Appeals Tribunal in this case was issued to the parties concerned on 7 February 1986. I understand further that the tribunal found in favour of the person concerned. He should now request payment of his redundancy lump sum from his former employer. If the employer fails to pay him the lump sum within a reasonable time, he should apply to the redundancy payments section of my Department on the prescribed form to have the lump sum paid to him direct from the Redundancy and Employers' Insolvency Fund.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Aylward Mr. Aylward

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: The amount of statutory redundancy lump sums paid from the Redundancy and Employers' Insolvency Fund to the employees of Clover Meats Limited, Christendom, Ferrybank, Waterford, following the closure of this plant in 1985 was £1,330,772.78.
